etymologies: Middle English: from a-‘in, on’ + round

notes.text: Are around and round (as preposition and adverbial particle) interchangeable? In US English, the normal form in most contexts is around; round is generally regarded as informal or nonstandard and is standard only in certain fixed expressions, as in the park is open year round and they went round and round in circles

definitions: located or situated on every side

examples.text: the mountains towering all around
a building visible for miles around

shortDefinitions: on every side

definitions: so as to surround someone or something

examples.text: everyone crowded around
a pool with banks all the way around

shortDefinitions: so as to surround person or thing

definitions: so as to give support and companionship

examples.text: sometimes you wonder how many friends will rally around you when your life hits rock-bottom

shortDefinitions: so as to give support and companionship

definitions: with circular motion

examples.text: the boats were spun around by waterspouts

shortDefinitions: with circular motion

definitions: so as to cover or take in the whole area surrounding a particular center

examples.text: she paused to glance around admiringly at the decor

shortDefinitions: so as to cover or take in whole area surrounding particular center

definitions: so as to reach everyone in a particular group or area

examples.text: he passed a newspaper clipping around

shortDefinitions: so as to reach everyone in particular group or area

definitions: so as to rotate and face in the opposite direction

examples.text: Jack seized her by the shoulders and turned her around
having him in my corner has turned my career around

shortDefinitions: to face in opposite direction

definitions: so as to lead in another direction

examples.text: it was the last house before the road curved around

shortDefinitions: so as to lead in another direction

definitions: used in describing the position of something, typically with regard to the direction in which it is facing or its relation to other items

examples.text: the picture shows the pieces the wrong way around

shortDefinitions: used in describing position of something

definitions: used to describe a situation in terms of the relation between people, actions, or events

examples.text: it was he who was attacking her, not the other way around

shortDefinitions: used to describe situation in terms of relation between people or events

definitions: in or to many places throughout a locality

examples.text: word got around that he was on the verge of retirement
his only ambition is to drive around in a sports car

shortDefinitions: throughout area

definitions: so as to reach a new place or position, typically by moving from one side of something to the other

examples.text: he made his way around to the back of the building
they went the long way around by the main road

shortDefinitions: so as to reach new place or position

definitions: used to convey an ability to navigate or orient oneself

examples.text: I like pupils to find their own way around

shortDefinitions: used to convey ability to navigate or orient oneself

definitions: used to convey the idea of visiting someone else

examples.text: why don't you come around to my office?

shortDefinitions: used to convey idea of visiting someone else

definitions: randomly or unsystematically; here and there

examples.text: one of them was glancing nervously around
John tried to focus on her but she kept moving around

shortDefinitions: here and there

definitions: in existence, in the vicinity, or in active use

examples.text: there was no one around
barley has been around for a long time
by being around I threaten her happiness

shortDefinitions: present or in evidence

definitions: near at hand

examples.text: he would want to have her around as much as possible

shortDefinitions: near at hand

definitions: approximately; about

examples.text: software costs would be around $1,500
I returned to my hotel around 3 a.m.

shortDefinitions: approximately

notes.text: Are around and round (as preposition and adverbial particle) interchangeable? In US English, the normal form in most contexts is around; round is generally regarded as informal or nonstandard and is standard only in certain fixed expressions, as in the park is open year round and they went round and round in circles

definitions: on every side of

examples.text: the palazzo is built around a courtyard
the hills around the city

shortDefinitions: on every side of

definitions: (of something abstract) having (the thing mentioned) as a focal point

examples.text: our entire culture is built around those loyalties
you can organize your essay around an existing critical controversy

shortDefinitions: having as focal point

definitions: in or to many places throughout (a community or locality)

examples.text: cycling around the village
a number of large depots around the country

shortDefinitions: in or to many places throughout

definitions: so as to pass (a place or object) in a curved or approximately circular route

examples.text: he walked around the airfield
it can drill around corners

shortDefinitions: following circular route

definitions: so as to encircle or embrace (someone or something)

examples.text: he put his arm around her
warming her hands around a cup of coffee
the polar vortex around Antarctica

shortDefinitions: so as to encircle or embrace
